Step: Step 2: Analyze your strengths and supports. In this step, you'll identify the strengths and supports that promote your resiliency and ability to navigate challenge and adversity (activity – identify 2 methods you’re using regularly) and identify and articulate the supports you still need to be fully resilient.
Name: The Resilient Leader at ASCD.org
Description: Great article on resilient leadership: the dos don'ts, and great questions to ask!

Step: Step 2: Analyze your strengths and supports. In this step, you'll identify the strengths and supports that promote your resiliency and ability to navigate challenge and adversity (activity – identify 2 methods you’re using regularly) and identify and articulate the supports you still need to be fully resilient.
Name: Building Resilience
Description: Have trouble getting by when the going gets tough? Everyone wants to perform well when the pressure's on, but a lot of us withdraw in times of stress or adversity. If you can build your resilience, you'll have an easier time facing new challenges and earn a valuable skill to offer employers.five training techniques to prepare for difficult situations, and five strategies for reflecting on them afterward. Find out where you are on the resilience scale, identify where you want to be, and learn strategies to close the gap

Step: Step 2: Analyze your strengths and supports. In this step, you'll identify the strengths and supports that promote your resiliency and ability to navigate challenge and adversity (activity – identify 2 methods you’re using regularly) and identify and articulate the supports you still need to be fully resilient.
Name: Emotional Agility by S. David
Description: Emotional agility is a four-step approach that allows us to navigate life’s twists and turns with self-acceptance, clear-sightedness, and an open mind. In her more than twenty years of research, Susan David has found that no matter how intelligent, resilient, or creative people are, when they ignore how situations or interactions make them feel, they miss opportunities to gain insight, getting hooked by thoughts, emotions, and habits that prevent them from reaching their full potential. Emotionally agile people experience the same stresses and setbacks as anyone else, but they know how to adapt, aligning their actions with their values and making small changes that lead to a life of growth.

Step: Step 2: Analyze your strengths and supports. Name: EdX Course: Becoming a Successful Leader
Description:
In this course, you will learn what successful 21st-century leaders look like and how you can adopt their inclusive leadership style. Using research and best practices, as well as stories from great leaders and everyday people, you will practice empowerment, accountability, courage, and humility—key leadership skills linked to inclusive, successful teams.

This online course seems appropriate for new/aspiring leaders that are looking to develop inclusive leadership skills. Also relevant for Step 8 (mentorship), Step 9 (presence), and Step 10 (personal philsophy).

Step: Step 2: Analyze your strengths and supports. Name: Future Skills Tracker: What's Your Public Service Profile?
Description:
A quick and easy self-assessment you can use to work out what skills and competencies are strengths — and which you should focus on for development to future-proof your career. 

Based on research into competency frameworks in different governments, this self- assessment tool also links you to resources to explore for further development.

Step: Step 4: Understand personal identity and examine unconscious bias for areas of growth
Name: How to Avoid Unconscious Bias in Leadership from Mind Resources Institute
Description: Short article introducing tips for leaders.

Step: Step 4: Understand personal identity and examine unconscious bias for areas of growth
Name: Howard Ross on Unconscious Bias
Description: Learn how unconscious bias affects our decision making and what impact that has in your world as a leader

Step: Step 4: Understand personal identity and examine unconscious bias for areas of growth
Name: Harvard Implicit Assumptions Test
Description:
Here is a tool that allows each of us to discover hidden cognitive biases. Most people are aware of their own overt biases, but it is very difficult for us to become aware of our covert biases. This is a test that can be taken by each individual for their own benefit.

Please note by completing the assessment you are consenting to your personal information being stored in the US. (User test results are anonymized and added to data sets to contribute to on-going research.)

Step: Step 4: Understand personal identity and examine unconscious bias for areas of growth

Description: This article provides a simple explanation of biases, in a non-threatening/nonjudgemental manner.

Step: Step 4: Understand personal identity and examine unconscious bias for areas of growth

Description: This article about ridding unconscious bias with curiosity and empathy is a quick read, with helpful examples and tips.

Name: What's your Leadership Identity? by Still Point Leadership
Description: Clear and articulate article about exploring your own leadership identity.

Step: Step 4: Understand personal identity and examine unconscious bias for areas of growth
Name: LEAD Route Cards from Leadership Exploration and Development FLNRORD
Description: LEAD Route Cards leverage the legacy work of the People Development Framework (PDF), launched in 2013. The Route Cards lead learners down a self-guided development path in various areas of focus. Using the 70-20-10 learning model, learners at all levels in the organization can explore new ways of approaching development and set a course for themselves to achieve their goals.
